brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a common issue in JUnit 4 parameterized test classes. These classes are annotated with @RunWith(Parameterized.class) but either do not include a data provider method annotated with @Parameterized.Parameters or this method has an incorrect signature. The data provider method should be public, static, and have a return type of Iterable or Object[]. The page suggests creating an empty parameter provider method or changing the signature of the incorrect data provider method.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'parameterized_test_class_without_data_provider_method' checks for each class in the project. If a class is annotated with @RunWith(Parameterized.class), it asserts that there exists a method in the class that is annotated with @Parameterized.Parameters, is static, and has a return type of either Iterable or Object[]. If such a method does not exist, it generates a message indicating the fully qualified name of the class and suggesting to create an empty parameter provider method or to change the signature of the incorrect data provider method.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/parameterized-tests-junit-5
Summary: This page provides a comprehensive guide on how to write parameterized tests in JUnit 5. It explains the importance of data provider methods and how they should be structured.

2. URL: https://www.vogella.com/tutorials/JUnit/article.html#parameterized-tests
Summary: This page provides a tutorial on writing parameterized tests in JUnit. It emphasizes the need for a data provider method and explains the correct signature for such methods.
